[blr]Pulls[/blr] to a [blr]standing[/blr] position. [blr]Cruises[/blr] around [blr]furniture[/blr]. [blr]Walks[/blr] with [blr]two hands held[/blr]. [blr]11[/blr] to [blr]12[/blr] months - [blr]walks[/blr] with [blr]one hand held[/blr]. [blr]13[/blr] to [blr]14[/blr] months - [blr]walks alone[/blr] [blr]15[/blr] to [blr]18[/blr] months - walks [blr]up stairs[/blr], can [blr]run[/blr] but [blr]falls easily[/blr]. [blr]Kicks ball[/blr] forward. [blr]2[/blr] years - [blr]walks[/blr] and [blr]runs[/blr] well. [blr]Jumps[/blr] in place.
review.child-fine-motor-development: [blr]birth[/blr] - [blr]reflexive grasp[/blr] [blr]3[/blr] months - inffective [blr]reach[/blr] for [blr]objects[/blr], voluntary [blr]grasp[/blr]. [blr]6[/blr] months - [blr]controlled reach[/blr]. [blr]6[/blr] to [blr]12[/blr] months - [blr]grasps[/blr] and [blr]puts objects[/blr] in [blr]mouth[/blr]. [blr]Pincer grasp[/blr] ([blr]thumb[/blr] and [blr]one[/blr] finger). [blr]Transfers[/blr] objects from [blr]one hand[/blr] to [blr]another[/blr]. [blr]1[/blr] to [blr]2[/blr] years - builds a tower of [blr]three[/blr] blocks. [blr]Self feeds[/blr] with small amount of [blr]assistance[/blr]. Brings [blr]spoon[/blr] to [blr]mouth[/blr]. [blr]Holds[/blr] drinks and [blr]cups[/blr]. [blr]2[/blr] to [blr]3[/blr] years - can [blr]turn pages[/blr] of a [blr]book[/blr]. [blr]Holds[/blr] crayons with [blr]thumb[/blr] and [blr]fingers[/blr], not [blr]fist[/blr]. Eats [blr]without assistance[/blr].
review.narcotic-dispension-law: It's the law that [blr]two nurses[/blr] (either [blr]LPNs[/blr] or [blr]RNs[/blr]) must [blr]sign[/blr] that the narcotic was [blr]wasted[/blr]. [blr]Placebos[/blr] are allowed by law but banned by the [blr]ethics committees[/blr]. A count must be done at the [blr]beginning[/blr] and [blr]end[/blr] of shift by law. A law requires all narcotics to be in a [blr]locked cabinet[/blr].
review.medication-administration: Medication should be checked [blr]three[/blr] times before administration.
review.blepharitis: Inflammation of a [blr]margin of an eyelid[/blr].
review.exopthalmos: [blr]Protrusion[/blr] of the [blr]eyeball[/blr], often seen in patients with [blr]hyperthyroidism[/blr].
review.presbyopia: [blr]Far sightetness[/blr]. Occurs [blr]naturally[/blr] with [blr]age[/blr] as [blr]elasticity[/blr] of the [blr]crystalline lens[/blr] is lost.
review.aplastic-anemia: Leads to [blr]pancytopenia[/blr] - a severe [blr]decrease[/blr] in [blr]all blood[/blr] cells. Some medications could cause this type of anemia like - [blr]cimetidine[/blr], [blr]NSAIDs[/blr], [blr]sulfonamides[/blr].
review.leukocytosis: Abnormal [blr]increase[/blr] in the number of [blr]white blood[/blr] cells - could be induced by some medications like [blr]lithium[/blr]. It's not as serious as [blr]leukocytopenia[/blr] (reduced [blr]white blood[/blr] cells).
review.granulocytes: Types of [blr]white blood[/blr] cells that include [blr]eosinophil[/blr], [blr]basophils[/blr] and [blr]netrophils[/blr]). [blr]Granulocytosis[/blr] or excess of these cells is often seen when the body is [blr]fighting an infection[/blr].
review.agranulocytosis: A lack of [blr]granulocytes[/blr] (not an [blr]increase in agranulocytes[/blr] as the name might suggest). Also known as [blr]granulocytopenia[/blr]. Some medications which could cause this are [blr]antithyroid[/blr] medications such as [blr]carbimazole[/blr] and [blr]methimazole[/blr], [blr]NSAIDS[/blr], and [blr]clozapine[/blr].
review.agranulocytes: Types of [blr]white blood[/blr] cells that include [blr]monocytes[/blr] and [blr]lymphocytes[/blr].
review.sickle-cell-anemia: A crisis could begin due to [blr]fever[/blr], [blr]stress[/blr] or [blr]dehydration[/blr]. Staying [blr]hydrated[/blr] is the most import aspect of the teaching. Follow a [blr]high calorie[/blr], [blr]high protein[/blr] diet. Avoid [blr]flying on a plane[/blr] - high [blr]altitudes[/blr] can precipitate a crisis due to [blr]body's higher demand for oxygen[/blr].
review.first-stage-of-labor: Extends until the cervix is [blr]fully dialted[/blr] at [blr]10[/blr] cm. Consists of [blr]two[/blr] stages - [blr]early[/blr] labor and [blr]active[/blr] labor. During early labor cervix dilates from [blr]0cm[/blr] to [blr]6cm[/blr]. A [blr]bloody show[/blr] appears which is the [blr]mucus plug[/blr] which [blr]covers the cervix[/blr]. During early labor the woman can [blr]take a walk[/blr], [blr]listen to relaxing music[/blr]. Can [blr]stay home[/blr] if the pregnancy is [blr]uncomplicated[/blr]. During active labor the cervix will dilate from [blr]6cm[/blr] to [blr]7[/blr] cm. Contractions will [blr]become stronger[/blr] and more [blr]regular[/blr]. The [blr]water might brake[/blr] at this point. Now is the time to [blr]head to the facility[/blr]. Average dilation rate of cervix is [blr]1[/blr] cm an hour. Active labor usually lasts between [blr]4[/blr] to [blr]8[/blr] hours. During active labor you can [blr]walk[/blr] or [blr]roll on a ball[/blr]. Active labor ends when the cervix dilates to [blr]7cm[/blr].
review.transition-stage-of-labor: Begins when the cervix is dilated by [blr]7cm[/blr] and ends when it's [blr]fully dilated[/blr] at [blr]10cm[/blr]. The most [blr]intense part of labor[/blr]. Contractions are the [blr]strongest[/blr]. Contractions come every [blr]2[/blr] to [blr]3[/blr] minutes and last [blr]60[/blr] to [blr]90[/blr] seconds.
review.second-stage-of-labor: Contractions are more [blr]spaced out[/blr], giving a [blr]chance to rest[/blr]. Urge to [blr]push[/blr] as baby [blr]gets lower[/blr].
review.third-stage-of-labor: Delivery of the [blr]placenta[/blr]. Usually have to give a small [blr]push[/blr] to separate the placenta. Uterus begins to [blr]contract[/blr].
review.hypotonic-solution: Examples are [blr]D2.5W[/blr], [blr]0.33%[/blr]NS, [blr]D5W[/blr] after metabolism - initially it's [blr]isotonic[/blr].
review.hypertonic-solutions: [blr]D5W[/blr] in [blr]0.9[/blr]% Normal Saline, [blr]D51/2NS[/blr]. Any Dextrose [blr]5[/blr]% in saline above [blr]1/4[/blr].
review.magnesium-sulfate: [blr]Tocolytic[/blr] agent given to women to reduce the [blr]intensity[/blr] of [blr]contractions[/blr] or to prevent [blr]premature labor[/blr].
review.carboprost-tromethamine: Brand name is [blr]Hemabate[/blr]. It is a naturally occuring [blr]prostaglandin F2a[/blr]. Used to [blr]induce labor[/blr] or to treat [blr]subinvolution[/blr]. Induces [blr]uterine contractions[/blr].
review.methylergovine: Brand name is [blr]methergine[/blr]. [blr]Ergot alkaloid[/blr] that improves [blr]uterine muscle tone[/blr] and [blr]strength[/blr] and [blr]timing[/blr] of contractions. Administed in [blr]post partum[/blr] care to help [blr]deliver the placenta[/blr] and help with [blr]uterine atony[/blr].
review.oral-potassium: Could be [blr]distasteful[/blr], capsules can be [blr]opened[/blr] and [blr]sprinkled[/blr] in [blr]apple sauce[/blr]. Potassium is [blr]irratating[/blr] to the [blr]esophagus[/blr] and should not be given on an [blr]empty stomach[/blr].
review.visual-acuity: Checked with a [blr]Snellen[/blr] chart, by having the patient stand [blr]20[/blr] feet away.
review.intro-ocular-pressure: Checked by a device called a [blr]tonometer[/blr].
review.gestational-length: After [blr]14th[/blr] week, fetal growth is about [blr]1[/blr] cm per week. At [blr]20[/blr] weeks the baby should be about [blr]20[/blr] centimeters or [blr]8[/blr] inches. Average birth length is [blr]50cm[/blr] or [blr]20[/blr] inches.
review.fetal-development-milestones: First trimester - development of [blr]major organs[/blr] and [blr]structures[/blr]. Second trimester - organs [blr]continue developing[/blr] and woman becomes [blr]aware of the pregnancy[/blr]. Third trimester - [blr]fetal lungs[/blr] begin [blr]movements of respiration[/blr] at [blr]24[/blr] weeks. Fetus can [blr]open its eyes[/blr] at [blr]28[/blr] weeks. [blr]Fingernails[/blr] comple development at [blr]38[/blr] weeks of gestation.
review.infant-apical-pulse: Auscultated at [blr]4th[/blr] intercostal left sternal border.
review.navajo-culture: Navajo are the [blr]second[/blr] most populous [blr]native American[/blr] cultures. Their main source of protein in [blr]sheep meat[/blr]. Major vegetables are [blr]corn[/blr] and [blr]squash[/blr].
review.arabic-culture: Do not consume [blr]juice[/blr] or [blr]beverages[/blr] until the [blr]meal is over[/blr].
review.african-american-culture: [blr]Graciously accept[/blr] all [blr]gifts[/blr] and do not [blr]reject[/blr] them.
review.diseases-of-the-nail: [blr]Onychomycosis[/blr] - nail [blr]fungus[/blr], causes [blr]thickening[/blr] of the nail and [blr]brittleness[/blr]. [blr]Onychomadesis[/blr] - [blr]proximal separation[/blr] of the nail bed due to a temporary [blr]sessation[/blr] of nail growth. [blr]Onychorrhexis[/blr] - [blr]brittle[/blr] nails, appears as [blr]vertical lines[/blr] and [blr]cracks[/blr] in the nail. Rhexis is "[blr]splitting[/blr]" in Greek. [blr]Onychia[/blr] - [blr]infection[/blr] of the [blr]soft parts[/blr] around the nail or the [blr]matrix beneath it[/blr]. [blr]Paronychia[/blr] - similar to [blr]onychia[/blr] as it's an [blr]infection[/blr] of the nail folds, but [blr]proximal ones[/blr].
review.transdermal-patch: May reinforce the patch with [blr]tape[/blr] if it starts to loosen.
review.rho-gam: Also known as [blr]Rho(D) immune globulin[/blr]. Administered at [blr]28[/blr] weeks of gestation and then again within [blr]72 hours[/blr] after delivery. If terminating pregnancy after [blr]13th [/blr] week, also administer within 72 hours of delivery. Contraindicated to patients who are [blr]Rh positive[/blr] or those who have [blr]elevated temperature[/blr].
review.Cushing-syndrome: Characterized by a [blr]chronic exposure[/blr] to a [blr]corticosteroid[/blr]. Could either be secondary due to [blr]medication[/blr] or [blr]primary[/blr].
review.hyperthyroidism: Treatment with [blr]propranolol[/blr] (to relieve [blr]cardiac manifestations[/blr]) and [blr]propylthiouracil[/blr] (if [blr]methimazole[/blr] did not work well) is common.
review.spinal-cord-damage: Gold standard to diagnose is a [blr]CT[/blr] scan.
review.dermatomes: C8 - can control [blr]shoulders[/blr] and entire [blr]length of the arm[/blr]. C4 - can control [blr]shoulders[/blr] T1 - control parts of muscles of [blr]underside of arms[/blr] T2 and below - control of [blr]torso[/blr] L1 and below - below the [blr]waist[/blr] S1 and S2 - lateral part of [blr]heels[/blr] and [blr]genitals[/blr]
review.insulin: Should not be [blr]shaken[/blr] because that causes [blr]bubbles[/blr] and [blr]froth[/blr] which could cause the insulin to [blr]stick to the vial[/blr]. Should be gently [blr]rolled[/blr] in the hands or [blr]turned upside down[/blr] a few times, but not [blr]vigorously shaken[/blr].
review.burns-fluid-resucitation:
Based on the [blr]Parkland formula[/blr], should be started in adults with [blr]15[/blr]% or greater surface area burned and children with [blr]10[/blr]% or more surface area affected. [blr]4ml[/blr] x [blr]%tba[/blr] x ([blr]body weight[/blr] in [blr]kg[/blr]) with [blr]50[/blr]% given in first [blr]8[/blr] hours and another [blr]50[/blr]% in the next [blr]16[/blr] hours.
For children, in addition to the formula above give: additional [blr]4ml[/blr]/kg for first [blr]10kg[/blr] of body weight additional [blr]2ml[/blr]/kg for second [blr]10kg[/blr] body weight additional [blr]1ml[/blr]/kg for [blr]remaining weight[/blr]
review.septic-shock: Fluid resucitation should be started at [blr]30ml[/blr]/kg Should start infusing an [blr]empirical antibiotic[/blr] (antibiotic directed against a [blr]likely cause[/blr]).
review.spontaneous-abortion: Occurs if the woman delivers before [blr]20[/blr] weeks (fetus is [blr]not able to survive before that[/blr]).
review.intra-cranial-pressure: Standard ICP is [blr]5[/blr] - [blr]15[/blr] mmHg. To decrease the pressure the head of bed should be at [blr]30[/blr]-[blr]40[/blr]%. Neck should [blr]not be flexed[/blr].
review.dicyclomine: Has [blr]antispasmodic[/blr] properties, and [blr]anticholinergic[/blr] properties. Used in treatment of [blr]irritable bowel syndrome[/blr]. Usually administed on [blr]PRN basis[/blr] for [blr]abdominal cramping[/blr]. Main adverse effect is [blr]dizzinees[/blr].
review.Indian-culture: Women wear a [blr]sari[/blr], which is a long dress. Majority of people follow a [blr]Hindu[/blr] religion ([blr]80[/blr]%), the largest minority is [blr]Muslim[/blr] ([blr]16[/blr]%) and the rest [blr]6[/blr]% are Christian, Buddhist, Sikh and Jains. Use [blr]prayer beads[/blr] called [blr]Japa Mala[/blr], which is also used in [blr]Buddhism[/blr].
review.infant-cardiac-problems: Early sign is [blr]trouble feeding[/blr]. Classical sign is [blr]irrtability[/blr].
review.assult-and-battery: Assualt is [blr]threatening[/blr] the client in [blr]fear[/blr]. Battery is [blr]touching[/blr] the client [blr]without consent[/blr].
review.atelectasis: Common complication in the [blr]post operative[/blr] period especially after [blr]abdominal surgeries[/blr], due to accumulation of [blr]mucus[/blr] due to inefficient [blr]throx expansion[/blr]. If it's not addressed it might progress to [blr]pneumonia[/blr]. If the client has to stay in bed they have to be [blr]supine[/blr] and head of bed needs to be [blr]elevated[/blr] or [blr]semi-recumbent[/blr] ([blr]30[/blr]-[blr]45[/blr] degrees). Encourage the client to cough at least [blr]10[/blr] times per hour.
review.type-1-diabetes: Eat [blr]15[/blr]-[blr]30[/blr] grams of a [blr]simple-carbohydrate[/blr] before [blr]exercising[/blr], not a [blr]complex carb[/blr] (since it takes a [blr]long time[/blr] to [blr]digest[/blr]).
review.simple-carbohydrate: 15 grams of simple carbohydrate examples: [blr]1 tablespoon[/blr] of sugar in water or [blr]honey[/blr]. [blr]1/2[/blr] cup of [blr]apple[/blr]/[blr]orange[/blr] juice or [blr]soda[/blr] [blr]1[/blr] cup of [blr]milk[/blr] [blr]3[/blr]-[blr]4[/blr] glucose tablets
review.Legionnaires-disease: [blr]Not transmissible[/blr] from person to person, so [blr]standard[/blr] precautions are used. Transmitted by [blr]inhaling droplets[/blr] of [blr]contaminated water[/blr].
review.hepatic-encephalopathy: [blr]Asterixis[/blr] is a common occurance, which is a [blr]flapping hand tremor[/blr].
review.venous-insufficiency: Associated with [blr]painless skin ulcers[/blr]. [blr]Brown[/blr] colored skin, near the [blr]ankles[/blr]. Plulse is [blr]present[/blr] and [blr]normal[/blr]. [blr]Edema[/blr] is common. Ulcers are [blr]painless[/blr] and appear on area near [blr]ankle[/blr] and [blr]tibia[/blr], they are very [blr]irregular[/blr] and [blr]shallow[/blr].
review.peripheral-arterial-disease: [blr]Dangle[/blr] the legs to increase perfusion. Pain worst at [blr]night[/blr] and after [blr]sleep[/blr]. [blr]Intermittent claudication[/blr] - Pain and cramping when [blr]exercising[/blr] that stops when you [blr]rest[/blr]. [blr]Cool[/blr] to touch and [blr]hairless[/blr] skin. [blr]Thick[/blr] toenails. Pulse is [blr]weak[/blr]. Ulcers located on [blr]ends of toes[/blr], [blr]top of feet[/blr], or [blr]sides of heels[/blr]. Ulcers look [blr]punched out[/blr]. [blr]Edema[/blr] is not commmon. Legs become [blr]red[/blr] with dangling.
review.turgor: Check [blr]turgor[/blr] midpoint right below the [blr]clavicles[/blr] or on the [blr]inner forearm[/blr].
review.contrast: Avoid taking [blr]metformin[/blr] before hand as it could cause contrast related [blr]nephrotoxicity[/blr] and [blr]lactic acidosis[/blr]. [blr]Metformin[/blr] should be [blr]stopped[/blr] immediately [blr]before[/blr] the procedure and witheld for at least [blr]48[/blr] hours.
review.milia: [blr]Tiny[/blr] white [blr]dots[/blr] that appear on the skin. Most often on [blr]infant[/blr] faces. Happens when [blr]skin flakes[/blr] become [blr]trapped[/blr] in pockets near the surface. [blr]Harmless[/blr] and goes away on its own.
review.tuberculosis: Common therapy is a coctail of [blr]4[/blr] drugs - [blr]isoniazid[/blr], [blr]rifampin[/blr], [blr]pyrazinamide[/blr] and [blr]ethembutol[/blr] for [blr]2[/blr] months, followed by [blr]4[/blr] months of just [blr]isoniazid[/blr] and [blr]rifampin[/blr]. All four drugs could cause [blr]liver damage[/blr], pay attention to [blr]jaundice[/blr] and [blr]clay colored stools[/blr]. Tuberculosis is no longer contagious after [blr]2 weeks[/blr] of antibiotic treatment. Isoniazid - Major sidefect is [blr]peripheral neuropathy[/blr]. Have to take a [blr]B complex[/blr] vitamin as isoniazid deplestes the stores of pyridoxine (B6). Has to be taken for at least 6 months. Rifampin - common side effect is your [blr]urine[/blr], [blr]sweat[/blr] and [blr]stool[/blr] become [blr]reddish orange[/blr]. Pyrazinamide - can cause [blr]hyperuricemia[/blr] or elevated [blr]uric acid[/blr] in the blood, could cause [blr]gout[/blr] and [blr]kidney stones[/blr]. Ethambutol - can cause [blr]vision loss[/blr], report loss of [blr]color vision[/blr], [blr]blurred vision[/blr] or increased [blr]light sensitivity[/blr].
review.prolapsed-cord: A medical [blr]emergency[/blr], [blr]stay[/blr] with the patient and [blr]call for help[/blr]. Don't [blr]handle the cord[/blr] or try to [blr]push it back in[/blr]. Try to [blr]lift[/blr] the fetus [blr]off the cord[/blr]. Place the client on [blr]left lateral[/blr], [blr]trendelenburg position[/blr]. Give [blr]oxygen[/blr] and prepare for [blr]emergency c-section[/blr].
review.tracheal-suctioning: Limit suction to [blr]100[/blr]-[blr]120[/blr] mmHg in adults and [blr]80[/blr]-[blr]100[/blr] in children. Limit duration to [blr]10[/blr]-[blr]15[/blr] seconds for adults and [blr]10[/blr] seconds for children. Avoid [blr]routine suctioning[/blr]. If the client has [blr]bradycardia[/blr] (from [blr]vagal response[/blr]) or [blr]tachycardia[/blr], suction [blr]fast[/blr] - [blr]5[/blr] second continuous or [blr]10[/blr] second intermittent. Advance catherter [blr]premeasured distance[/blr] only.
review.knee-arthroplasty: Place the client in a [blr]continous passive motion machine[/blr] that moves the leg for them for [blr]6[/blr]-[blr]8[/blr] hours per day. This increases the [blr]range of motion[/blr]. [blr]Wheel chair [/blr] is not used to geet around, [blr]crutches [/blr] are used. Placing a [blr]pillow [/blr] underneath the knee is not recommended as it may increase the chance for [blr]contracture [/blr]. [blr]Ice [/blr] may be applied for a maximum of [blr]20 [/blr] minutes during the first 24 hours. [blr]Anticoagulats [/blr] are started and maintained for at least [blr]14 [/blr] days to prevent DVT.
review.hypokalemia: Major effect on [blr]breathing[/blr] - weakens muscle [blr]needed to breathe[/blr]. Results in [blr]shallow respirations[/blr].
review.oral-contraceptives: Increase the risk of [blr]clots[/blr] and [blr]strokes[/blr] in women who [blr]smoke[/blr] more than [blr]10 cigarettes[/blr] per day.
review.phenylketonuria: Impaired [blr]metabolism[/blr] of an essential amino acid [blr]phenylalanine[/blr]. Foods high in [blr]protein[/blr] have this amino acid - such as [blr]meats[/blr], [blr]cheeses[/blr], [blr]eggs[/blr]. Formula used for infants is called Lofenalac.
review.antipsychotics: Could cause an [blr]extrapyramidal syndrome[/blr] - which can cause [blr]parkinson[/blr] like symptoms such as [blr]shuffling gait[/blr] and [blr]stooped posture[/blr]. [blr]Tardive dyskinesia[/blr] is a form of [blr]extrapyramidal syndrome[/blr] which mostly involves the [blr]face[/blr]. Could cause acute [blr]dystonic reaction[/blr] - this could cause [blr]lyringial spasms[/blr] - usually treated with [blr]anticholinergics[/blr] and [blr]benzodiazapeines[/blr]. Could cause [blr]neuroleptic-malignant-syndrome[/blr] - symtoms are [blr]high fever[/blr] ([blr]102[/blr]-[blr]104F[/blr]), [blr]muscle rigidity[/blr]
review.malignant-hyperthermia: Genetic disorder characterized by abnormal reaction to [blr]anesthetic drugs[/blr]. Usually occurs during induction with agenets such as [blr]succinylcholine [/blr] and [blr]halothane [/blr].
review.nsaids: [blr]Antacids[/blr] should be taken with this class of drugs to prevent [blr]GI bleeding[/blr].
review.pulse: During an infant cardiac arrest the best place to check for pulse is the [blr]brachial artery[/blr]. During an adult cardiac arrest the best place to check for pulse is the [blr]carotid artery[/blr].
review.eclampsia: Severe outcome of [blr]pre-eclampsia[/blr], results in [blr]blood pressure[/blr] so high that it causes [blr]seizures[/blr].
review.pre-eclampsia: Symptoms include [blr]epigastric pain[/blr], espcially in the [blr]right side[/blr]. Changes in [blr]vision[/blr] such as [blr]blurring[/blr]. [blr]Proteinuria[/blr].
review.septic-shock: Type of [blr]distributed shock[/blr]. First phase is the [blr]warm shock[/blr] alsko known as [blr]hyperdynamic shock[/blr]. The blood pressure at this stage is usually [blr]within normal limits[/blr], the cardiac output and heart rate [blr]increase[/blr] and there is [blr]vasodialation[/blr], causing the skin to [blr]feel warm[/blr]. Prompt intervention of [blr]IV fluids[/blr] and [blr]antibiotics[/blr] at this stage [blr]improves the outcomes greatly[/blr].
review.pregnancy: [blr]Left side lying[/blr] position is the best for expectant mothers, as it promotes [blr]optimal placental oxygenation[/blr].
review.retinal-detachment: [blr]Medical emergency[/blr]. Instruct the client to [blr]stop all head and eye movements[/blr] and apply [blr]an eye patch[/blr] to the eye.
review.iron-deficiency-anemia: Infants [blr]12[/blr]-[blr]16[/blr] months of age are at high risk for developing it because by that age [blr]maternal stores have depleted[/blr].
review.bradycardia: [blr]Epinephrine[/blr] is the drug of choice for [blr]bradycardia[/blr] in a child. If the child has an IV the dose of [blr]epinephrine[/blr] should be [blr]1[/blr]:[blr]10000[/blr] if there is no [blr]IV[/blr] in place then must use [blr]1[/blr]:[blr]1000[/blr] dose concentration. The dosage calculation for children is [blr]0.1[/blr]ml/kg. [blr]Epinephrine[/blr] should be given every [blr]3[/blr]-[blr]5[/blr] minutes until [blr]bradycardia[/blr] is resolved.
review.intraosseous-access: Used mostly for [blr]children[/blr] and [blr]newborns[/blr]. Used because they are [blr]faster to establish[/blr] to [blr]deliver treatment[/blr] in a patient in whom [blr]IV lines[/blr] are [blr]difficult to establish[/blr]. Patients are [blr]switched over[/blr] to [blr]IV medication[/blr] within [blr]24 hours[/blr].
review.burns: [blr]Intramuscular[/blr] administion is avoided as patients with burns are usually [blr]hemodynamically unstable[/blr] and so [blr]tissue[/blr] and [blr]muscle[/blr] perfusion and [blr]absorption[/blr] is not dependable.
review.intubation: First drug to be administed is [blr]propofol[/blr] to [blr]induce sleep[/blr]. Then administer a [blr]paralytic agent[/blr] such as [blr]vecuronium[/blr], [blr]rocuronium[/blr] or [blr]succinylcholine[/blr].
review.thrombophlebitis: Can be caused by failure to change [blr]IV sites[/blr] every [blr]72[/blr] hours.
review.asceptic-technique: Intended to try to [blr]minimize[/blr] contamination with pathogens. [blr]Sterile[/blr] technique on the other hand is aimed at [blr]eliminating all pathogens[/blr].
review.immunocompromised: Frequent and meticulous [blr]hand washing[/blr]. [blr]Fresh fruits[/blr] and [blr]flowers[/blr] can contain [blr]pathogens[/blr], all [blr]fruits[/blr] and [blr]vegies[/blr] should be [blr]cooked[/blr]. [blr]Plants[/blr] and [blr]flowers[/blr] are [blr]not allowed[/blr] in the room. [blr]Neutropenia[/blr] is particulary dangerous as it could lead to [blr]life threatening infections[/blr]. [blr]Neutropenic[/blr] paties should have a [blr]private room[/blr].
review.semi-private-room: Hospital room with [blr]two beds[/blr] and a [blr]curtain[/blr] or [blr]divider[/blr] between them.
review.terbutaline: [blr]Beta 1[/blr] agonist - causes [blr]vasodilation[/blr] [blr]Tocolytic[/blr] used to prevent [blr]premature labor[/blr]. Could [blr]raise blood sugar[/blr] levels. Could [blr]lower serum potassium[/blr], stop the infusion if [blr]potassium[/blr] drops below [blr]3.5 mEq/L[/blr]. Being a [blr]beta 1 agonist[/blr] one of the side effects is [blr]tachycardia[/blr]. Infusion should be stopped if [blr]heart rate[/blr] exceeds [blr]120 bpm[/blr]. Infusion should be stopped if [blr]blood pressure[/blr] drops below [blr]90/60[/blr].
review.appendicitis: An examination will reveal [blr]rebound tenderness[/blr] at [blr]McBurney's[/blr] point - point [blr]2/3[/blr] of length between [blr]naval[/blr] and [blr]anterior superior iliac spine[/blr]. [blr]Rovsing[/blr] sign - [blr]tenderness[/blr] on [blr]right side[/blr] when [blr]left side[/blr] is [blr]palpated[/blr]. [blr]Orburator[/blr] sign - [blr]pain[/blr] on movement of the [blr]hip joint[/blr] while [blr]knee is flexed[/blr]. If [blr]pain suddently disappears[/blr], appendix must have [blr]ruptured[/blr]. Must do a [blr]CT scan[/blr] to confirm.
review.cushing-disease: Diet should be low [blr]sodium[/blr], high [blr]protein[/blr], and low [blr]fat[/blr], increased [blr]calcium[/blr] and [blr]vitamin D[/blr]. Higher [blr]fiber foods[/blr] to [blr]lower cholesterol[/blr] are also encouraged.
review.bulimia-nervosa: [blr]Buproprion[/blr] is contraindicated because of the [blr]weight loss[/blr] associated with it.
review.smoke-alarm: Change batteries when the [blr]day-light saving time changes[/blr], which is approximately [blr]twice[/blr] a year.
review.ectopy: [blr]Changes[/blr] in otherwise [blr]normal heart beat[/blr]. Most common forms are [blr]PVCs[/blr] and [blr]PVAs[/blr] ([blr]premature atrial contrations[/blr]).
review.respiratory-distress: In children significantly increases [blr]insensible fluid loss[/blr] and therefore causes [blr]dehydration[/blr]. Requires an addition of [blr]20[/blr]-[blr]50[/blr]% of fluid than normal to compensate.
review.respiratory-acidosis: Takes [blr]3[/blr]-[blr]5[/blr] days to become [blr]compensated[/blr]. Acute respiratory acidosis is [blr]uncompensated[/blr].
review.iron-deficiency-anemia: Causes the RBCs to be [blr]hypochromic[/blr] ([blr]pale[/blr], lacking [blr]central color[/blr]) and [blr]microcytic[/blr] ([blr]small[/blr]).
review.medication-refusal: First inquire about the [blr]reason for refusal[/blr]. Then [blr]educate[/blr] the client about [blr]the benefits[/blr] of the medecine and [blr]address[/blr] their concerns. If the client still refuses to take the medication, [blr]document it[/blr] and [blr]inform the primary health care provider[/blr].
review.opioid-analgesia: Morphine equivalency is a term that describes [blr]comparative potency[/blr] of an opiod analgestic when compared with [blr]perenteral morphine[/blr].
review.bed-bath: A client can have [blr]prefenreces[/blr] how often they wish to bathe. Once a week is [blr]ok[/blr] also. As long as the client remains [blr]hygenic[/blr].
review.nasogastric-tube: If the tube is correctly inserted into the stomach the sample pH should be at or below [blr]3.5[/blr] pH.
review.tetrology-of-fallot: Mnemonic to remember this condition is [blr]PROVe[/blr]. [blr]P[/blr] - [blr]Pulmonary inficibular stenosis[/blr] [blr]R[/blr] - [blr]Right ventricular hypertrophy[/blr] [blr]O[/blr] - [blr]Overriding aorta[/blr] [blr]V[/blr] - [blr]Ventral Septal Defect[/blr]
review.open-angle-glaucoma: Common risk factors are: [blr]older age[/blr], [blr]african american[/blr] ethnicity, [blr]type 2 diabetes[/blr].
review.enterohepatic-circulation: [blr]Bile acids[/blr] and [blr]salts[/blr] are [blr]absorbed[/blr] into the [blr]intestine[/blr] and then [blr]re-excreted[/blr] again to [blr]reabsorb[/blr] as much nutrients as possible.
review.myocardial-enzymes: [blr]Troponin[/blr] - the gold standard, rises about [blr]3[/blr]-[blr]4[/blr] hours after MI and remains raised for [blr]3 weeks[/blr]. It's also the most [blr]specific[/blr] biomarker for MI. [blr]CPK-MB[/blr] - levels rise in [blr]3[/blr]-[blr]6[/blr] hours and peak in [blr]24[/blr] hours. Not the most [blr]specific[/blr] to the heart though. [blr]Creatine kinase[/blr] - also found in [blr]brain[/blr], [blr]muscles[/blr] and other tissue. Any time there is [blr]muscle damage[/blr] there is an elevation of this enzyme. Negative result of this are a good indication to [blr]rule out[/blr] an MI, but positives are [blr]non specific[/blr]. [blr]Myglobin[/blr] - present in all [blr]muscles[/blr], only [blr]negative[/blr] results are considered to [blr]rule out[/blr] MI.
review.alcohol-withdrawal: Symptoms typically evolve in 4 phases: Early withdrawal - mild [blr]tremors[/blr], start about [blr]4[/blr]-[blr]12[/blr] hours after last drink and are accompanied by other symptoms like [blr]nausea[/blr], [blr]insomnia[/blr], and [blr]headaches[/blr]. Patient is still [blr]A and O[/blr]. Moderate withdrawal - patient is somewhat [blr]confused[/blr] and [blr]hyperactive[/blr], in this stage remember that "[blr]everything increases[/blr]" - [blr]blood pressure[/blr], [blr]temperature[/blr], [blr]heart rate[/blr], [blr]respirations[/blr] etc. Strong withdrawal - [blr]auditory[/blr] or [blr]visual hallucinations[/blr]. Begins [blr]12[/blr]-[blr]24[/blr] hours after last drink, can last [blr]1[/blr] to [blr]2[/blr] days. Usually the patinets are [blr]alrets[/blr] and not [blr]disoriented[/blr] but report seeing [blr]bugs[/blr] in the room. These can be very [blr]scary[/blr] to the patient, nurse needs to [blr]stay with them[/blr], [blr]notify the physician[/blr] and implement [blr]seizure precautions[/blr]. Severe withdrawal - [blr]delirium tremens[/blr]. Typically occurs [blr]3[/blr]-[blr]5[/blr] days after the last drink. Considered a [blr]medical emergency[/blr]. [blr]Sympathetic[/blr] overdrive - [blr]fever[/blr] and [blr]hypertension[/blr] which can progress to [blr]cardiovascular collapse[/blr]. [blr]Hallucinations[/blr] continue but are more [blr]immersive[/blr] and can eveolve into [blr]tonic-clonic seizures[/blr].
review.umbilical-cord: Normal number of vessels is [blr]three[/blr]. [blr]Two arteries[/blr] and [blr]one vein[/blr]. [blr]Two arteries[/blr] return wastes to the mother. The [blr]single vein[/blr] carries [blr]nutrients[/blr] and [blr]oxygen[/blr] to the baby. The color of the cord is usually [blr]blue[/blr] and [blr]white[/blr].
review.neonatal-jaundice: Occurs in [blr]60[/blr]-[blr]80[/blr]% of term newborns in the [blr]first week[/blr] of life. Jaundice first becomes visible on [blr]face[/blr] and [blr]forehead[/blr] and then on [blr]extremities[/blr] and [blr]trunk[/blr]. This is called a [blr]cephalocaudal progression[/blr]. Newborn should be tested for [blr]Rh[/blr] incompatibility and [blr]hyperbilirubinemia[/blr]. Press [blr]finger[/blr] over [blr]bridge of nose[/blr] to blanch the skin and watch for yellow discoloration on blanching.
review.mongolian-spot: [blr]Temporary[/blr] spot found in babies of [blr]Mediterranin[/blr], [blr]Latin American[/blr] or [blr]Asian[/blr] descent. Will [blr]fade[/blr] in [blr]months[/blr] or [blr]years[/blr].
review.heme-cell-family:
Common myeloid progenitor - Produces [blr]megalocaryocyte[/blr] (produces [blr]platelets[/blr]), [blr]erythrocyte[/blr], [blr]mast cell[/blr] (release [blr]histamine[/blr]), [blr]myeloblast[/blr]. Myeloblast - produces [blr]neutrophils[/blr], [blr]eosinophils[/blr], [blr]basophils[/blr] as well as [blr]monocytes[/blr]. Monocytes - found in [blr]blood[/blr], migrate to [blr]tissue[/blr] to form [blr]macrophages[/blr]. Neutrophils - most [blr]abundant[/blr] leukocyte, accounding for [blr]40[/blr]-[blr]70[/blr]% of them. Highly [blr]motile[/blr], capable of [blr]chemotaxis[/blr]. Capable of [blr]mobilizing[/blr] other cells and can [blr]phagocytize[/blr] pathogens. Eosinophils - respond to [blr]parasitic[/blr] infections and [blr]allergic[/blr] reactions, account for about [blr]2[/blr]-[blr]3[/blr]% of leukocytes. Basophils - [blr]least[/blr] common type of leukocytes, accounting for about [blr]0.5[/blr] - [blr]1[/blr]% of these cells. Appear in inflammatory [blr]allergic[/blr] reactions.
Common lymphoid progenitor - produces [blr]B lymphocytes[/blr], [blr]T lymphocytes[/blr], and [blr]Natural Killer Cells[/blr], these account for [blr]30[/blr]-[blr]60[/blr]% of all cells. B lymphocytes - integral part of [blr]humoral immunity[/blr] system. When they detect an [blr]antigen[/blr] they turn into an [blr]antibody secreting plasma[/blr] cells. T lymphocytes - [blr]CD8+[/blr] killer T cells contain [blr]cytotoxins[/blr] and are able to kill other cells directly. [blr]CD4+[/blr] helper T cells - activate [blr]B memory cells[/blr] and other [blr]T cells[/blr]. Natural killer cells - work in an analogous way to [blr]T cells[/blr] by utilizing [blr]cytotoxins[/blr], but do not require [blr]activation[/blr] to kill cells that are missing the [blr]self markers[/blr].
review.multiple-myeloma: Proliferation of plasma cells, leading to [blr]bone pain[/blr] and [blr]loss[/blr]. Affects the ability to [blr]fight infections[/blr]. Bone scans are usually [blr]falsely negative[/blr] and are therefore [blr]not performed[/blr]. Usually normal [blr]X rays[/blr] are ordered.
review.bone-scan: A small amount of [blr]radionucleotide[/blr] is injected and scans are done at [blr]intervals[/blr]. Asked to [blr]drink a lot of water[/blr] to [blr]rid[/blr] of radiation. Asked to [blr]empty bladder[/blr] before the scan, as they have to stay there for a while.
review.nutrition: [blr]45[/blr]-[blr]65[/blr]% of calories should come from [blr]complex carbs[/blr] that are rich in [blr]fiber[/blr] such as whole wheat [blr]pasta[/blr], [blr]brown rice[/blr], [blr]granola[/blr]. [blr]20[/blr]-[blr]30[/blr]% from [blr]fat[/blr] and [blr]10[/blr]-[blr]20[/blr]% from [blr]protein[/blr].
review.Weber-test: Can distinguish between [blr]unilateral conductive hearing loss[/blr] ([blr]middle[/blr] ear) or [blr]sensorineural[/blr] ([blr]inner[/blr] ear) hearing loss. Cannot determine [blr]which ear has hearing loss[/blr]. Tuning fork is placed against a [blr]bone[/blr] on [blr]top of the head[/blr] or [blr]face[/blr] and if the affected ear hears the noise [blr]louder[/blr] then it is a [blr]conductive hearing loss[/blr], if the normal ear hears it louder then it's [blr]sensorimotor[/blr] hearing loss. [blr]Rinne[/blr] test must be performed to detect hearing loss that [blr]patient is not aware of[/blr].
review.speaking-with-deaf: Good [blr]lighting[/blr], [blr]rephrase[/blr] rather than [blr]repeat[/blr], do not [blr]raise voice[/blr].
review.diaper-dermatitis: Less in [blr]breast fed[/blr] babies. [blr]Barrier[/blr] cream should not be [blr]removed[/blr] with every [blr]diaper change[/blr].
review.toddler-nutrition: Finger foods like [blr]diced bananas[/blr] and [blr]avocados[/blr]. [blr]Skim milk[/blr] should not be offered until [blr]2[/blr] years of age, babies need [blr]fat[/blr] in whole fat milk for [blr]brain[/blr] development. [blr]Grapes[/blr] should be [blr]cut[/blr] in small pieces to reduce chances of [blr]choking[/blr]. Toddlers could be very picky and could throw tamper tantrums to get the [blr]food they like[/blr]. Decrease in apetite because of a significantly [blr]decreased growth[/blr] (compared to [blr]infant[/blr] years). Should not [blr]insist[/blr] the child to eat if they have [blr]no interest[/blr] in eating or making them [blr]finish the plate[/blr]. Like [blr]routine[/blr] and [blr]predictability[/blr]. Serve [blr]favorite food[/blr] along with a [blr]small amount[/blr] of [blr]new[/blr] food to try. Focus on [blr]high nutrition[/blr] not [blr]high calories[/blr]. Don't use [blr]sweets[/blr] as [blr]rewards[/blr], don't withold [blr]favorite food[/blr] as [blr]punishment[/blr].
review.contraindications-to-breastfeeding: Clients with active [blr]varicella[/blr]. Active [blr]TB[/blr] infection that is [blr]untreated[/blr]. Active [blr]herpes[/blr] on the [blr]breast[/blr].
review.advanced-directives: Different from a [blr]DNR[/blr]. Lists [blr]directives[/blr] that the client [blr]may wish[/blr] to be [blr]implemented[/blr]. DNR simply says [blr]do not resucitate[/blr] if the [blr]heart stops[/blr].
review.stroke: Keep head of bed elevated by about [blr]15[/blr]-[blr]30[/blr] degrees, not [blr]higher[/blr] (not [blr]high Fowler's[/blr] position) to keep [blr]IC pressure[/blr] down.
review.hypoglycemia: Treatment should occur if sugar falls below [blr]70mg[/blr]/dL. If patinet is [blr]concious[/blr] give a [blr]simple oral carb[/blr]. If [blr]unconcious[/blr] then administer [blr]1mg[/blr] of [blr]glucagon[/blr] subq. or [blr]25[/blr]-[blr]50ml[/blr] of [blr]50[/blr]% dextrose IV.
review.droplet-precautions: Staff who are not wearing a mask should keep [blr]3[/blr] feet ([blr]1 meter[/blr]) away.
review.monoamine-oxidase-inhibitors: May precipitate a [blr]hypertensive crisis[/blr], especially in presence of [blr]foods[/blr] that contain [blr]tyramine[/blr].
review.bipolar-mania: For acute mania lithium must be at [blr]1[/blr]-[blr]1.5[/blr] mEq/L For acute mania the gold standard of treatment is mood stabilizers such as valproic acid, it has a fast onset. For maintance dose it must be at [blr]0.6[/blr]-[blr]1.2[/blr] mEq/L
review.positron-emission-tomography: Long procedure, can last as long as [blr]2[/blr] hours. A [blr]radio isotope[/blr] is administered as a [blr]dye[/blr] (client may feel the [blr]flush[/blr] and [blr]metalic taste[/blr]) and the client waits on the stretcher for [blr]35[/blr]-[blr]45[/blr] minutues while the isotope circulates. Increase [blr]fluids[/blr]. Can visualize [blr]brain activity[/blr] by highlighting [blr]glucose[/blr]. NPO [blr]4 [/blr]- [blr]6 [/blr] hours prior. Detects [blr]glucose [/blr] metabolism, so necessary to check patients [blr]glucose [/blr] prior. Levels above [blr]150 [/blr] and below [blr]60 [/blr] could affect the scan.
review.retroperitoneal-bleeding: [blr]Cullen's[/blr] sign - is [blr]bruising[/blr] around the [blr]umbilicus[/blr]. [blr]Gray turner's[/blr] sign - [blr]brusing[/blr] around the [blr]flank[/blr]. Gross [blr]hematuria[/blr].
review.Cullens-sign: Brusing around the [blr]umbilicus[/blr]. Could indicate acute [blr]pancreatitis[/blr], ruptured [blr]ectopic pregnancy[/blr], [blr]aortic[/blr] rupture.
review.sepsis: In early [blr]sepsis[/blr] all organ systems are [blr]involved[/blr] and it's important to [blr]identify[/blr] this stage. Follow the SIRS ([blr]Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome[/blr]) guidelines: If [blr]two[/blr] or more of these criteria are present then the client is progressing toward sepsis. Heart rater [blr]>90[/blr] bpm. Temperature [blr]> 101F[/blr] OR less than [blr]96.8F[/blr] Respiratory rate [blr]>20 bpm[/blr] or [blr]PaCO2[/blr] less than [blr]32[/blr] mmHg. WBC [blr]> 12,000/mL[/blr] or > [blr]10%[/blr] bands ([blr]immature neturophils[/blr]) present.
review.bands: [blr]Immature neutrophils[/blr], produced in [blr]high amounts[/blr] when there is an [blr]active infection[/blr].
review.thoracentesis: A [blr]14[/blr] or [blr]16[/blr] guage needle is used to [blr]drain[/blr] the [blr]air[/blr] or [blr]fluid[/blr] from the [blr]lungs[/blr] to [blr]relieve the pressure[/blr].
review.age-appropriate-toys: Birth - [blr]2[/blr] months: [blr]mobile[/blr] maintained [blr]8[/blr]-[blr]10[/blr] inches from [blr]face[/blr]. [blr]2[/blr]-[blr]4[/blr] months - [blr]rattles[/blr], cradle [blr]gym[/blr]. [blr]4[/blr]-[blr]6[/blr] months - [blr]brightly colored[/blr] toys (small enough to [blr]grasp[/blr], large enough [blr]not to swallow[/blr]). [blr]6[/blr]-[blr]9[/blr] months - [blr]large[/blr] toys with [blr]bright colors[/blr], [blr]movable[/blr] parts and [blr]noisemakers[/blr]. [blr]9[/blr]-[blr]12[/blr] months - [blr]books[/blr] with [blr]pictures[/blr], large [blr]push[/blr] and [blr]pull[/blr] toys, [blr]teddy bears[/blr].
review.staff-conflict-resolution: Ask the staff who are in conflict to [blr]summarize[/blr] each others [blr]complaints[/blr] and have the opponent [blr]validate the summary[/blr]. This promotes [blr]theraputic communication[/blr] and is effective at [blr]conflict resolution[/blr].
review.biophysical-profile:
Test done after [blr]28th[/blr] week of pregnancy. Combines an [blr]ultrasound[/blr] with [blr]non-stress test[/blr]. Sonogram asses [blr]fetal breath movements[/blr], [blr]fetal tone[/blr], [blr]amniotic fluid index[/blr] and [blr]general movements[/blr]. Each criteria carries a weight of [blr]2[/blr] points: Reactive non stress test - 2. Fetal tone - 2 Amniotic fluid index (amount of fluid present) - 2 fetal breath movements - 2 general movements - 2
[blr]8-10[/blr] - healthy baby [blr]6[/blr] - needs a [blr]retest[/blr] in [blr]24 hours[/blr] [blr]0-4[/blr] - baby needs to be delivered
review.fetal-non-stress-test: May be done after [blr]26[/blr]-[blr]28[/blr] weeks of pregnancy. Done using a [blr]fetal heart rate monitor[/blr], may use [blr]sound[/blr] to [blr]wake the baby up[/blr]. Heart rate should [blr]rise[/blr] when the baby [blr]moves[/blr]. Reassuring if the fetal heart rate [blr]increases[/blr] by at least [blr]15[/blr] beats over [blr]baseline[/blr] lasting at least [blr]15[/blr] seconds, within a [blr]20[/blr] minute window. This is called a [blr]reactive[/blr] test, a [blr]non reactive[/blr] test requires [blr]further assessment[/blr].
review.fundal-height: Expected to reach umbilicus at [blr]20[/blr] weeks. Then [blr]1 cm[/blr] per week until [blr]36th[/blr] week.
review.fetal-movements: First periced by the mother at [blr]16[/blr]-[blr]20[/blr] weeks as [blr]flutter[/blr] in [blr]lower[/blr] abdomen.
review.colostomy: To prevent leakage don't let the bag [blr]get too heavy[/blr], empty it is when it's a [blr]1/3[/blr] full.
review.infant-examination: Any invasive assessments like the [blr]ears[/blr] and [blr]mouth[/blr] are likely to cause [blr]crying[/blr] and so are best completed [blr]last[/blr]. Parents should [blr]hold the infants[/blr] to make them feel more comfortable. Ausculate heart and breath sounds when infant is [blr]quiet[/blr] and [blr]asleep[/blr].
review.thyroid-storm: Acute response which could come after [blr]thryoid surgery[/blr] or [blr]manipulation[/blr] of the thyroid. Defined by a [blr]hypermetabolic[/blr] state. Elevated [blr]blood pressure[/blr], [blr]heart rate[/blr], [blr]respirations[/blr] and [blr]temperature[/blr].
review.pregnancy-breast-tenderness: Apply [blr]cold compresses[/blr] and wear a [blr]supportive bra[/blr].
review.iv-lidocaine: Suppresses [blr]ventricular irritability[/blr]. Should not be use in [blr]heart block[/blr], becuase it can [blr]diminish[/blr] ventricular [blr]escape beats[/blr].
review.heart-block-poem: If [blr]R is far from P[/blr], then you have [blr]first degree[/blr]. If [blr]longer, longer, longer[/blr] ([blr]PR interval[/blr]) [blr]drop[/blr], then you have [blr]Wenkebach[/blr] ([blr]Mobitz I[/blr]). If [blr]some Ps don't get through[/blr] then you have [blr]Mobitz II[/blr]. If[blr] Ps and Qs don't agree[/blr] then you have [blr]third degree[/blr].
review.complete-heart-block:
Ventricular escape rythm is usually [blr]60 beats[/blr] or [blr]less[/blr]. Ventricles must not be [blr]slowed[/blr] with drugs such [blr]lidocaine[/blr] as that could lead to a [blr]cardiac arrest[/blr].
[blr]Pacemaker[/blr] is the treatment of choice for complete heart block. [blr]Isoproterenol[/blr] is used to [blr]accelerate[/blr] ventricular escape rythm as a [blr]temporary measure[/blr]. [blr]Epinephrine[/blr] is usually administered for complete heart block, [blr]2[/blr]-[blr]10[/blr] mcg/min and [blr]titrated[/blr] based on response. Other drugs that may be used are [blr]atropine[/blr] and [blr]dopamine[/blr]. [blr]Transcutaneous pacing[/blr] may be used temporarily.
Some medications that could cause heart block are [blr]Digoxin[/blr], [blr]beta blockers[/blr], [blr]calcium channel blockers[/blr].
review.digoxin: Apical pulse shold be taken for a [blr]full minute[/blr] before [blr]medication administration[/blr]. If the pulse is less than [blr]60[/blr], dose should be [blr]witheld[/blr] and [blr]provider notified[/blr]. Symptoms of digoxin toxicity are [blr]gastrointestinal[/blr] such as [blr]N and V[/blr], [blr]halos around lights[/blr]. Pediatric patients mostly just present with [blr]bradycardia[/blr] or [blr]arrhythmias[/blr]. Must monitor [blr]potassium[/blr] during digoxin administration. If patient is hypokalemic digoxin [blr]toxicity[/blr] could be [blr]worsened[/blr]. If hyperkalemic digoxin will [blr]not be as effective[/blr]. Normal levels is between [blr]0.5[/blr] - [blr]2ng/ml[/blr] When ordered as an IV push, it has to be pushed over [blr]5 [/blr] min, in order to do that you must [blr]dilute [/blr] it with [blr]normal saline [/blr] to [blr]5 [/blr]- [blr]10ml [/blr] bolus. Could cause [blr]heart block [/blr]. Avoid [blr]licorice [/blr] extracts as they act similar to aldosterone, increasing [blr]sodium [/blr] retention and [blr]potassium [/blr] excretion. Monitor for [blr]yellow [/blr] or [blr]green [/blr] vision changes. Other electrolytes that could cause toxicity are [blr]magnesium [/blr] and [blr]calcium [/blr], [blr]hypomagensemia [/blr] and [blr]hypercalcemia [/blr] could contribute to toxicity.
review.wheel-chair-bound: Teach to do [blr]wheelchair pushups[/blr] every [blr]15 minutes[/blr].
review.nutrition: Provide [blr]1.25[/blr] - [blr]1.5[/blr] g/kg of protein per day. Provide diets rich in [blr]zinc[/blr], vitamins [blr]A[/blr], [blr]B[/blr], [blr]C[/blr], and [blr]sulfur[/blr] if [blr]immobility[/blr] is present.
review.schitzophrenia: Positive symptoms - Perceptions ([blr]hallucionations[/blr], [blr]delusions[/blr]), thought [blr]content[/blr] ([blr]paranoia[/blr], [blr]religiousness[/blr], [blr]magical thinking[/blr]), thought [blr]patterns[/blr] ([blr]concrete[/blr] thinking, [blr]word salad[/blr], [blr]associative looseness[/blr]), [blr]sense[/blr] of [blr]self[/blr] ([blr]depersonalization[/blr], [blr]echolalia[/blr] - [blr]immitation[/blr] of [blr]speech[/blr], [blr]echopraxia[/blr] - [blr]immitation[/blr] of [blr]movement[/blr]). Negative symptoms - [blr]Affect[/blr] ([blr]flat[/blr], [blr]apathy[/blr]), [blr]Volition[/blr] (deteriorating [blr]appearance[/blr], [blr]ambivalence[/blr]), [blr]Relationships[/blr] (social [blr]isolation[/blr]), [blr]Psychomotor[/blr] behaviours ([blr]pacing[/blr] and [blr]rocking[/blr], [blr]posturing[/blr]) Cognitive symptoms - Difficulty [blr]focusing[/blr], [blr]working memory[/blr] problems, poor [blr]executive function[/blr] (imparied [blr]judgement[/blr] and [blr]decision making[/blr]).
review.informed-concent: Mentally ill individuals [blr]retain the right[/blr] to [blr]refuse treatment[/blr] until the [blr]court rules[/blr] that they can't.
review.phenytoin: Used to [blr]prevent seizures[/blr]. Comes as a [blr]suspension[/blr] and must be [blr]shaken[/blr] to administer a proper dose. Side effects - inhibits [blr]mucosal absorption[/blr] of [blr]folic acid[/blr] ([blr]B9[/blr]), interferes with metabolism of [blr]vitamin D[/blr], and could cause [blr]hypocalcemia[/blr]. Can cause [blr]gingival hyperplasia[/blr] (excessive [blr]growth of gums[/blr]) in [blr]long term use[/blr], excessive growth of [blr]body hair [/blr], effect is minimized with frequent [blr]dental care[/blr]. Can turn the urine [blr]pink[/blr] or [blr]red-brown[/blr]. Decreases [blr]oral contraceptive[/blr] effectiveness. Should not be taken with [blr]calcium carbonate[/blr] because it decreases the effectiveness of [blr]phenytoin[/blr]. Theraputic dose is [blr]10 [/blr] - [blr]20 [/blr] mcg/mL of blood. Toxicity is any level above [blr]40 [/blr] mcg/mL, symptoms are [blr]nystagmus [/blr], changes in [blr]mental status [/blr], and [blr]unsteady gait [/blr].
review.folic-acid: Also known as [blr]vitamin B9[/blr]. Good sources are [blr]green leafy vegetables[/blr], [blr]legumes[/blr], [blr]tomatoes[/blr], various [blr]fruits[/blr].
review.Jehovas-Witnesses: Don't believe in [blr]blood donation[/blr] or even [blr]autologous transfusions[/blr]. Have to use alternative [blr]volume expanders[/blr] rather than [blr]blood[/blr].
review.fetal-heart-rate-patterns: Variable decelerations - [blr]cord compression[/blr] - change [blr]maternal posistion[/blr], Give [blr]O2[/blr] at [blr]8[/blr]-[blr]10L[/blr]/min, [blr]notify provider[/blr] Early decelerations(occuring at the same time as contractions) - [blr]normal pattern[/blr] Late decelerations (occuring after the contractions) - [blr]placental insufficiency[/blr], predictor for lower [blr]APGAR scores[/blr]. Position [blr]on side[/blr], [blr]raise legs[/blr] if [blr]hypotensive[/blr], Give [blr]O2[/blr] at [blr]8[/blr]-[blr]10L[/blr]/min.
review.client-in-labor: Check for [blr]dilation[/blr] and [blr]efacement[/blr]. Place a [blr]fetal heart rate monitor[/blr] and assess the [blr]baseline rate[/blr].
review.umbilical-cord-care: Avoid [blr]tub baths[/blr] until cord has [blr]fallen off[/blr] on [blr]its own[/blr]. Keep [blr]dry[/blr] and [blr]exposed to air[/blr]. Usually separates in [blr]5[/blr]-[blr]15[/blr] days.
review.log-rolling: Maintains proper [blr]spine alignment[/blr] while [blr]turning a patient[/blr]. Requires minimum of [blr]3[/blr] nurses, one [blr]at the head[/blr] and [blr]two[/blr] at the [blr]side[/blr]. The nurse at the [blr]head[/blr] uses [blr]hands[/blr] to make sure the neck is [blr]straight[/blr] at [blr]all times[/blr]. [blr]Two[/blr] nurses stay at the [blr]same side[/blr] and [blr]turn[/blr] the patient. The patient does not [blr]help at all[/blr].
review.toddler-safety: Keep stairs [blr]off limits[/blr] by having gates at the [blr]top[/blr] and [blr]bottom[/blr]. Do not feed [blr]popcorn[/blr], uncut [blr]grapes[/blr], [blr]hot dog[/blr] pieces or [blr]berries[/blr].
review.ileal-conduit: [blr]Urinary diversion[/blr] when the [blr]bladder[/blr] can not be used. Creates a pocket out of [blr]intestine[/blr]. Collection appliance should be changed every [blr]3[/blr]-[blr]7[/blr] days to prevent [blr]leakage[/blr]. Bag should be emptied when it's [blr]1/3[/blr] full.
review.cerebro-spinal-leak: [blr]Double ring[/blr] appears on gauze if the fluid is [blr]CSF[/blr].
review.NIH-Stroke-Scale:
[blr]Level Of Conciousness[/blr] - 0 [blr]alert[/blr] and [blr]keenly responsive[/blr], 1 not [blr]alert[/blr] but [blr]arousable[/blr], 2 not [blr]alert[/blr] and requires [blr]strong stimulation[/blr], 3 [blr]totally unalert[/blr] [blr]Visual Fields[/blr] - 0 no [blr]visual loss[/blr], 1 partial [blr]hemianopia[/blr], 2 complete [blr]hemianopia[/blr], 3 [blr]bilateral hemianopia[/blr] ([blr]blindess[/blr]) [blr]Facial Palsy[/blr] - 0 [blr]symmetrical movements[/blr], 1 minor paralyis (flattened [blr]nasolabial fold[/blr], [blr]assymetry[/blr] on [blr]smiling[/blr]), 2 partial [blr]paralysis[/blr] of [blr]one side[/blr], 3 complete [blr]paralysis[/blr] of [blr]one[/blr] or [blr]both[/blr] sides [blr]Motor Arm[/blr] - arms extended [blr]90[/blr] degrees if standing or [blr]45[/blr] degrees if supine - 0 no [blr]drift[/blr] over [blr]10[/blr] seconds, 1 limb gets up to [blr]90[/blr] deg but [blr]falls[/blr] a little before [blr]10[/blr] seconds are over, 2 - limb cannot get to [blr]90[/blr] deg, 3 - limb [blr]falls[/blr], 4 - no [blr]movement[/blr]. [blr]Motor Leg[/blr] - always tested [blr]supine[/blr], raise leg to [blr]30[/blr] degrees for [blr]5[/blr] seconds - 0 no [blr]drift[/blr] for [blr]5[/blr] seconds, 1 [blr]falls[/blr] at the end of [blr]5[/blr] seconds not [blr]hitting bed[/blr], 2 leg [blr]falls[/blr] to bed before [blr]5[/blr] seconds are over, 3 - leg falls [blr]immediately[/blr], 4 - no [blr]movement[/blr]. [blr]Limb Ataxia[/blr] - 0 [blr]absent[/blr], 1 present in [blr]1[/blr] limb, 2 present in [blr]both limbs[/blr] [blr]Sensory[/blr] - 0 normal, 1 feels [blr]pinprick[/blr] but with [blr]mild loss[/blr] of [blr]sense[/blr], 2 no [blr]feeling[/blr] at all [blr]Aphasia[/blr] - 0 none, 1 mild, 2 severe, 3 [blr]global[/blr] ([blr]mute[/blr]). [blr]Dysarthria[/blr] - 0 none, 1 mild, 2 moderate [blr]Extinction[/blr] and [blr]Inattention[/blr] - 0 none, 1 present, 2 [blr]profound[/blr] (loss of [blr]comprehension[/blr] of [blr]space[/blr] on side [blr]contralateral[/blr] of the lesion).
Interpretation: 0 - no stroke symptoms [blr]1[/blr]-[blr]4[/blr] - minor stroke [blr]5[/blr]-[blr]15[/blr] - moderate stroke [blr]16[/blr]-[blr]20[/blr] - moderate to severe stroke [blr]21[/blr]-[blr]42[/blr] - severe stroke
review.hyperglycemia: Exessive [blr]sleepiness[/blr], saying they can't [blr]wake up[/blr] today.
review.hypokalemia: Think [blr]low[/blr] and [blr]slow[/blr] - [blr]hypotension[/blr], [blr]lethargy[/blr], [blr]bradycardia[/blr], depressed [blr]St segment[/blr], [blr]flat[/blr] or [blr]inverted[/blr] T wave, prominient [blr]U[/blr] wave, [blr]leg cramps[/blr], decreased [blr]DTRs[/blr] and [blr]bowel sounds[/blr], [blr]constipation[/blr], [blr]low[/blr] and [blr]shallow[/blr] respirations, muscle [blr]weakneass[/blr].
review.chloasma: [blr]Mask[/blr] of [blr]pregnancy[/blr] - [blr]blotchy[/blr], [blr]brown[/blr] hyperpigmentation of skin over [blr]cheeks[/blr], [blr]nose[/blr] and [blr]forehead[/blr].
review.linea-nigra: Dark line that runs down the [blr]middle of abdomen[/blr], could be one of [blr]earlies signs[/blr] of pregnancy, usually appears at about [blr]5[/blr] months of pregnancy ([blr]20[/blr] weeks).
review.first-trimester: Marked by hypertrophy of [blr]mamary glands[/blr] and [blr]hyperpigmentation[/blr] of the [blr]areola[/blr].
review.syndrome-of-inappropriate-antidiuretic-h: Could occur in patients with [blr]lung cancer[/blr]. Treated with [blr]diuretics[/blr] such as [blr]furosemide[/blr]. Results in [blr]hypervolemia[/blr] and [blr]dilutional hyponatremia[/blr]. Maintain fluid restriction of [blr]800[/blr]-[blr]1000ml[/blr]/day.
review.anti-retro-viral-therapy: Long term therapy results in [blr]hyperlipidemia[/blr] and [blr]cardiovascular disease[/blr]. Effectively suppress the viral load within [blr]12[/blr]-[blr]24[/blr] weeks of therapy.
review.meningitis: Inflammation of the [blr]three layers[/blr] of the [blr]brain's sheath[/blr]. [blr]Dura[/blr] mater, [blr]Arachnoid[/blr] mater, and [blr]pia[/blr] mater. [blr]Nuchal ridgidity[/blr] and [blr]photophobia[/blr] are the hallmark symptoms.
review.client-cohort: Clients who can [blr]share the room togheter[/blr]. Must be of the same [blr]gender[/blr]. Client with a [blr]healing surgical wound[/blr] should not be placed in a room with a client with an [blr]infection[/blr].
review.infant-stools: [blr]Mucus[/blr] in stool is not normal even with [blr]meconium[/blr]. Breastfed babies will have a [blr]seedy[/blr], [blr]tan[/blr] colored stools.
review.hypoalbuminemia: Causes a loss of [blr]oncotic pressure[/blr] in the vessels and causes fluids to move into [blr]tissues[/blr] causing [blr]edema[/blr].
review.gastrostomy-tube: Feedings should be administed over a period of at least [blr]30 minutes[/blr]. [blr]Liquid medications[/blr] that are meant to be taken by mouth should [blr]not be administered[/blr] through a tube because they may contain excessive [blr]sorbitol[/blr] which could cause [blr]diarrhea[/blr]. Maintain head of bed at [blr]30[/blr]-[blr]45[/blr] degrees [blr]during[/blr] and at least [blr]1 hour[/blr] after [blr]feedings[/blr]. First [blr]assess the abdomen[/blr] and [blr]bowel sounds[/blr], note the last [blr]bowel movement[/blr]. After verifying [blr]gastric residual[/blr] and [blr]placement[/blr], [blr]flush[/blr] the tube with [blr]water[/blr] and start the feeding. May need to hold feeding if residual volume is above [blr]100mL[/blr]. Check residual every [blr]4[/blr]-[blr]6[/blr] hours if on [blr]continuous feeding[/blr] and just before every [blr]intermittent[/blr] feeding.
review.LPN-delegation: Has limited [blr]IV administration[/blr] abilities, some could be [blr]qualified[/blr].
review.alteplase: Used to dissolve [blr]blood clots[/blr] in blood vessels, used in [blr]heart attacks[/blr] and [blr]strokes[/blr]. Must be used with caution in known or suspected [blr]infections[/blr] at the [blr]central line insertion site[/blr], since it could release a [blr]localized infection[/blr] into [blr]systemic circulation[/blr].
review.epidural-hematoma: Perform frequent [blr]neuro assessments[/blr]. Could affect the clients ability to [blr]move the legs[/blr] and [blr]void[/blr], assess those parameters.
review.forbidden-abbreviations: [blr]U[/blr] - write out "units" [blr]QD[/blr] - write "daily" No [blr]trailing zeros[/blr] and always a [blr]leading zero[/blr] ex no 5.0 mg or .5mg, instead write [blr]5mg[/blr] and [blr]0.5mg[/blr] [blr]MSO4[/blr] and [blr]MgSO4[/blr] - could be confused for each other, write out the [blr]full names[/blr], [blr]morphine sulfate[/blr] and [blr]magnesium sulfate[/blr]. HS could be interpreted as half strength or at bed time and is no longer approved to be used, words must be written out.
review.influenza: Greatest risk is [blr]age over 65[/blr]. Those diagnosed with [blr]heart[/blr], [blr]lung[/blr] or other [blr]chronic illness[/blr] including [blr]diabetes[/blr]. Residents of [blr]long term care facilities[/blr]. Everyone over the age of [blr]6 months[/blr] should get the vaccine. Quadrivalent means that there are [blr]2 influenza A[/blr] viruses and [blr]2 influenza B[/blr] viruses the vaccine protects against. Could be given either [blr]nasally[/blr] or by [blr]injection[/blr]. [blr]Nasal[/blr] administration is not recommended for children [blr]under 2 years old[/blr], adults [blr]50 years[/blr] and older, [blr]pregannt women[/blr] and [blr]immunocompromised[/blr], theses individuals need to receieve the vaccine by injection. [blr]Pregnant women[/blr] should get an influenza vaccine. Individuals who are receiving [blr]antibiotics [/blr] for a mild illness could still get the inactivated vaccine. Cell based and recombinant vaccines are [blr]egg free[/blr] and are safe to use in people with egg allergies. Adjuvants in vaccines like [blr]FLUAD Quadrivalent[/blr] are added to increase immune response in people [blr]65[/blr] and older. High dose flu vaccines like Fluzone High-Dose Quadrivalent contains [blr]four times[/blr] the antigen than the equivalent standard vaccine. Only approved for people [blr]65[/blr] and older. It is [blr]24[/blr]% more effective in preventing flu in adults 65 and older.
review.skin-allergy-testing: > Client has to wait [blr]20[/blr] minutes in the clinic after testing as a safety measure just in case of a delayed reaction. Multiple [blr]intradermal[/blr] injections are adminstered.
review.hemophelia: The most frequent site of bleeding is into [blr]muscles[/blr] and [blr]joints[/blr]. Repeated bleeding episodes could cause changes in [blr]bones[/blr] and [blr]muscles[/blr] and lead to crippling [blr]knee[/blr] and [blr]joint deformities[/blr]. Treatment is infusion of [blr]IV clotting factors[/blr], not [blr]pills[/blr]. [blr]Dehydration[/blr] does not cause an excerbation. [blr]Blood transfusions[/blr] are not required unless the client [blr]lost a lot of blood[/blr].
review.hypothermia: Increases [blr]oxygen consumption[/blr]. Is labled when body temperature drops below [blr]95F[/blr]
review.general-anasthesia:
Common adverse effects:: [blr]Sore throat[/blr] after a breathing tube. [blr]Shivering[/blr] and feeling [blr]cold[/blr]. [blr]Nausea[/blr] and [blr]vomiting[/blr] Difficulty [blr]passing urine[/blr].
Severe adverse affects of anesthesia: respiratory rate less than [blr]12[/blr] bpm. [blr]Hypothermia[/blr] [blr]Malignant hyperthermia[/blr]
review.activated-partial-thromboplastin-time: Normal value is [blr]30[/blr]-[blr]40[/blr] when not on any medications. Theraputic range when on heparin is [blr]2x[/blr] control, which is [blr]60-80[/blr]
review.low-molecular-weight-heparin: Often does not require [blr]monitoring blood work[/blr], because natural [blr]heparin[/blr] is much more [blr]unpredictable[/blr] in action.
review.heparin: Antidote is [blr]protamine[/blr], which binds to it and neutralizes it. [blr]1[/blr] mg neutralizes [blr]100[/blr] units. Has a [blr]short [/blr] half life, so stopping it for even [blr]30 min [/blr] would [blr]lower [/blr] aPTT. Both aPTT and Platelet count need to be monitored because heparin can induce thrombocytopenia. If platelet counts drop by 50% or more it needs to be reported.
review.diabetes-and-steroids: If a rise in [blr]blood glucose[/blr] is noted a provider should be alereted as an increase in [blr]antidiabetic regiment[/blr] might be required.
review.cholecystitis: Assessing [blr]fluid[/blr] and [blr]electrolytes[/blr] is important in these clients because they often present with [blr]hypokalemia[/blr] and [blr]hypomagnesemia[/blr] due to vomiting. Can cause [blr]clay colored stools[/blr].
review.magnesium-sulfate: [blr]Calcium gluconate[/blr] is an antidote. Suppressed [blr]deep tendon reflexes[/blr] is a sign of [blr]toxicity[/blr], so check [blr]patellar[/blr] reflexes.
review.pre-eclampsia: Excess [blr]stimulation[/blr] can trigger [blr]seizure activity[/blr], so [blr]limit visitors[/blr] and [blr]dim lights[/blr].
review.electro-convulsive-therapy: Contraindication is [blr]osteoporosis[/blr], brittles bones could be damaged during hard [blr]muscle contractions[/blr].
review.cane: Handle of the cane should be around [blr]hip level[/blr].
review.fat-embolism: Usually occur as a result of [blr]long bone[/blr] fractures. [blr]Petechiae[/blr] are seen on the chest in [blr]50[/blr]-[blr]60[/blr]% of cases, but could also be present on the [blr]face[/blr] and [blr]arms[/blr]. Other symptoms include [blr]dyspnea[/blr] and [blr]tachypnea[/blr]. Mental symtpoms include [blr]apprehension[/blr] and [blr]confusion[/blr].
review.sudden-infant-death-syndrome: Infants should not sleep in [blr]car seats[/blr] or [blr]strollers[/blr] or [blr]swings[/blr] as they may [blr]slump[/blr] enough to [blr]obstruct the airway[/blr]. Should not use [blr]blankets[/blr], instead use [blr]pajamas[/blr] or [blr]sleepers[/blr] and dress them [blr]warmly[/blr] for sleep. Risk factors include: [blr]male[/blr] gender, [blr]African American[/blr] or [blr]Native American[/blr] descent, [blr]overheating[/blr], mothers who [blr]smoke[/blr] or [blr]smoked[/blr] prenatally, exposure to [blr]tobacco smoke[/blr], prenatal use of [blr]alcohol[/blr] or [blr]drugs[/blr], infants who experienced an apparent [blr]life threatening event[/blr] that included cyanosis, pallor, [blr]choking[/blr] or [blr]gagging[/blr].
review.age-related-eye-changes: [blr]Arcus senilis[/blr] - white, gray or [blr]bluish[/blr] ring around the iris is a common finding in older adults. [blr]Presbyopia[/blr] - farsightedness Need for [blr]additional light[/blr] to see clearly.
review.cataract-surgery: Avoid [blr]movement[/blr] of the eye. Avoid exposing the eye to [blr]water[/blr], lifting heavy items, [blr]coughing[/blr], [blr]straining[/blr]. Wear an [blr]eye patch[/blr] at night and [blr]glasses[/blr] during the day. Avoid prolonged [blr]reading[/blr] or [blr]eye strain[/blr].
review.pharmacological-stress-test: [blr]Dobutamine[/blr] is used to increase HR, BP and contractility. Clinets need to be [blr]NPO[/blr] for [blr]3[/blr] hours. Caffeine is avoided for [blr]24[/blr] hours prior. Vasodialators used could cause [blr]flushing[/blr] and [blr]nausea[/blr]. Test takes [blr]3[/blr]-[blr]4[/blr] hours. Ensure someone is there to [blr]assist taking the client home[/blr]. Do not [blr]smoke[/blr] the day of the test.
review.oral-care: Apply a [blr]water soluble[/blr] moisturizer to lips. Rinse mouth with a [blr]50:50[/blr] dilution of [blr]hydrogen peroxide[/blr] and [blr]normal saline[/blr]. Position the clinet on the side with head of bed raised [blr]30[/blr]-[blr]45[/blr] degrees to avoid [blr]aspiration[/blr].
review.deep-vein-thrombosis: [blr]Homan[/blr] sign - [blr]calf pain on dorsiflextion of ankle[/blr]. Could result as an adverse effect of [blr]erythropoetin[/blr].
review.erythropoetin: Adverse affect is a [blr]deep-vein-thrombosis[/blr]. Could decrease [blr]blood glucose[/blr] by increasing [blr]glucose[/blr] uptake in cells.
review.Christianity: Eucharist is a [blr]ritual that commemorates the Last Supper[/blr], by [blr]drinking wine and eating a bread wafer[/blr].
review.Islam: End of life care in Islam involves [blr]facing the dying client to the East towards Mecca[/blr].
review.Catholicism: [blr]Sacrament of the sick[/blr] - also called [blr]Unction[/blr], anointing of the palms and forehead and face. [blr]Last Rites[/blr] - prayers and sometimes [blr]holy communion[/blr] administered to someone who is dying. Cannot be performed [blr]after someone has died[/blr].
review.Orthodox-Jewdaism: Believe that [blr]pain management[/blr] and [blr]quality of life[/blr] during end of life care is important.
review.total-parenteral-nutrition: Client could experience [blr]hypoglycemia[/blr] if the TPN is [blr]stopped too quickly[/blr]. Contains [blr]10[/blr]-[blr]50[/blr]% dextrose. Usually contains [blr]additional insulin[/blr].
review.percutaneous-transluminal-coronary-angio: [blr]Minimally[/blr] invasive procedure to open [blr]blocked[/blr] or [blr]stenosed coronary arteries[/blr] using a [blr]baloon stent[/blr]. It's usually a [blr]same day procedure[/blr] and the client is usually discharged home in [blr]6[/blr]-[blr]12[/blr] hours. Most common complication is a [blr]groin hematoma[/blr] which opens an [blr]arterial bleed[/blr]. To prevent this, [blr]minatain pressure[/blr] on the site with a [blr]pressure dressing[/blr] and a [blr]sand bag[/blr]. Instruct the client to keep the affected leg [blr]straight[/blr]. Assess the 6 P's - [blr]pulse[/blr], [blr]poikilothermia[/blr], [blr]parasthesia[/blr], [blr]paralysis[/blr], [blr]pain[/blr], [blr]pallor[/blr]. [blr]Femoral[/blr] or [blr]radial[/blr] artery is accessed during a cardiac catheterization. If the bleed does occur, apply [blr]direct manual pressure[/blr] to the [blr]puncture site[/blr] and [blr]notify the provider[/blr].
review.droplet-precautions: Must wear a [blr]regular mask[/blr] if providing care within [blr]3 feet[/blr] of the client.
review.transmission-precautions: Hepatitis A - [blr]contact[/blr] precautions. Methicillin-resistant-staphylococcus-aureus (MRSA) - [blr]contact[/blr] precautions. Mycobacterium tuberculosis - [blr]airborne[/blr] precautions. Robeola (measles) - [blr]airborne[/blr] precautions. Varicella (chickenpox) - [blr]airborne[/blr] and [blr]contact[/blr] (until [blr]lesions have healed[/blr]) precautions. Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) - [blr]droplet[/blr] precautions. Neisseria meningitidis - [blr]droplet[/blr] precautions. Pertussis - [blr]droplet[/blr] precautions.
review.Haemophilus-influenzae-type-b: Does not cause [blr]influenza[/blr] (the [blr]flu[/blr]). Can cause severe infections of the [blr]meninges[/blr] ([blr]brain[/blr] and [blr]spinal cord[/blr]) and [blr]bloodstream[/blr] infections. Can cause many different kinds of infections depending on the inf[blr]ected body part[/blr] most common are [blr]pneumonia[/blr], [blr]meningitis[/blr], and [blr]blood stream[/blr] infections. Children need [blr]3[/blr]-[blr]4[/blr] vaccine shots at various ages - at [blr]2[/blr] months, [blr]4[/blr] months, [blr]6[/blr] months, and [blr]12[/blr]-[blr]15[/blr] months. [blr]Older children[/blr] and [blr]adults[/blr] usually do not need an Hib vaccine
review.heart-failure: Elevated [blr]brain natriuretic peptide[/blr] (greater than [blr]100pg[/blr]/mL) could indicate [blr]heart failure[/blr].
review.human-papilloma-virus: Vaccine is recommened to children [blr]11[/blr]-[blr]12[/blr] years of age.
review.osteoporosis: Risk factors include [blr]European American[/blr] and [blr]Asian[/blr] women, not [blr]African American[/blr].
review.ringworm: Caused by a [blr]fungus[/blr]. Could happen on the [blr]scalp[/blr] and present as red [blr]circular[/blr] patches.
review.impetigo: Common, hightly [blr]contagious[/blr] skin infection that mainly affects [blr]infants[/blr] and [blr]young children[/blr]. Caused by a [blr]streptococcos[/blr] and [blr]staphylococcal[/blr] infections. Main symptom is [blr]red vesicles[/blr] or postules with [blr]honey[/blr] colored crust that form around the [blr]nose[/blr] and [blr]mouth[/blr]. Sores could be covered with a [blr]bandage[/blr] to prevent [blr]contact infections[/blr]. Requires [blr]direct skin to skin contact[/blr] to transmit. [blr]Contact[/blr] precautions could be implemented. Treatment usually involves either topical or oral [blr]atibiotics[/blr]. Topical ones such as [blr]mupirocin[/blr] are used for a [blr]few sores[/blr], while oral ones are used if there are [blr]a lot of sores[/blr].
review.group-a-streptococcus: Most common agent in this group is [blr]Streptococcus pyogenes[/blr]. Responsibe for [blr]strep throat[/blr] ([blr]streptococcus pharyngitis[/blr]) and [blr]impetigo[/blr]. Gram [blr]positive[/blr], look like [blr]chains of spheres[/blr] under a microscope. [blr]Beta[/blr] hemolytic streptococci could cause more severe reactions such as [blr]necrotizing fascitis[/blr]. Complications of GAS infections could reflect on [blr]kidneys[/blr] (causing [blr]glomerulonephritis[/blr]) and [blr]rheumatic fever[/blr] (affects the [blr]heart valves[/blr] and [blr]joints[/blr])
review.staphylococcus-aureus: Gram [blr]positive[/blr], looks like [blr]grape clusters[/blr] under a microscope. Most common cause of skin conditions such as [blr]boils[/blr], [blr]furuncles[/blr] and [blr]cellulitis[/blr]. It could also sometimes cause [blr]pneumonia[/blr]. Most strains have become resistent to [blr]penicillin[/blr]. Treatments include penicillin derivatives like [blr]oxacillin[/blr], and other antibiotics such as [blr]cefazolin[/blr]. For methycillin resistant staphylococcus aureus, best choice is [blr]vancomycin[/blr].
review.gram-positive-bacteria: Antibiotics used are usually [blr]beta-lactam[/blr] type, such as [blr]Penicillin[/blr] or [blr]Amoxicillin[/blr].
review.streptococcus-pneumoniae: Most common bacteria in causing [blr]bacterial pneumonia[/blr]. Gram [blr]positive[/blr], [blr]alpha[/blr] hemolytic, so don't cause [blr]complete hemolysis[/blr] and the red blood cell walls [blr]remain intact[/blr].
review.scabies: Caused by a [blr]female mite[/blr] burrowing underneath the the skin. Transmitted by [blr]direct contact[/blr] and is [blr]highly contagious[/blr]. Usual areas of infection are around [blr]skin folds[/blr]. Treatment includes [blr]5% permetherin[/blr] and [blr]cool compresses[/blr] and [blr]calamine lotion[/blr] and [blr]histamines[/blr]. Initially rash and itching may [blr]worsen[/blr] during treatment, but scabies usually resolves in [blr]4 weeks[/blr]. All clothes should be [blr]washed[/blr] and [blr]dried[/blr] with [blr]high heat[/blr]. Mites could only live [blr]3[/blr]-[blr]4[/blr] [blr]days[/blr] away from human skin, so place all items that can't be washed into a [blr]bag[/blr] with [blr]air squeezed out[/blr] and store for [blr]2 weeks[/blr]. Animals [blr]do not spread human scabies[/blr]. They are not caused by [blr]unclean environments[/blr].
review.cord-cutting: Cutting a cord early deprives the baby of the [blr]blood[/blr] that is still in the [blr]placenta[/blr]. Waiting to cut the cord increases the risk of [blr]intra-ventricular-hemorrhage[/blr] (due to increased [blr]blood pressure[/blr]) and increased [blr]blood volume[/blr]. Risks of cutting the cord late include [blr]polycythemia[/blr] ([blr]thicker[/blr] blood due to increase in [blr]red blood cells[/blr]) and increase in the incidence [blr]intra-ventricular-hemorrhage[/blr] as well as increase in incidence of [blr]jaundice[/blr] (due to excessive [blr]red blood cell breakdown[/blr]).
review.polycythemia: Condition of [blr]too many red blood cells[/blr] causing blood to become [blr]thicker[/blr].
review.intra-ventricular-hemorrhage: Sometimes occurs in newborns, especially [blr]premature babies[/blr] due to extremely [blr]fragile[/blr] blood vessels. Condition is quite rare after [blr]one month[/blr] of age. Treatment - [blr]there is no current therapy except supportive measures[/blr] such as [blr]spinal tap[/blr] to relieve pressure, [blr]ventricular shunt[/blr] to drain fluid or [blr]blood transfusion[/blr] to improve blood counts. Light bleedings have [blr]no significant effects[/blr], more significant bleeds could lead to [blr]movement problems[/blr] and [blr]developmental delays[/blr].
review.angina: Variant angina - also known as [blr]Prinzmetal's[/blr] angina or [blr]vasospastic[/blr] angina, occurs due a [blr]vasospasm[/blr] of the [blr]coronary artery[/blr] and usually happens [blr]at rest[/blr], during the [blr]quietest parts of the day[/blr] like [blr]early morning[/blr] and [blr]night[/blr]. Produces [blr]same pain[/blr] as regualr angina. Managed with [blr]calcium channel blockers[/blr]. Stable angina - occurs [blr]after exercise[/blr] and is treated with [blr]nitroglycerin[/blr]. Unstable angina - less [blr]predictable[/blr] and is [blr]not relieved[/blr] with [blr]nitroglycerin[/blr].
review.graves-disease: Caused by increase in [blr]thyroid hormone[/blr]. Symptoms include [blr]diaphoresis[/blr], and increase in [blr]apetite[/blr] (due to increase in [blr]metabolism[/blr], however [blr]weight[/blr] is still significantly [blr]decreased[/blr]). [blr]Exophtalmos[/blr] (bulging of the eyes) is a [blr]severe sign[/blr] of Graves disease, once the disease progresses to this point, [blr]exopthalmos[/blr] is [blr]irriversible[/blr].
review.meconium: Usually passed within [blr]24[/blr] hours in [blr]99[/blr]% of healthy, full term infants, 100% should pass it by [blr]48[/blr] hours. In preterm infants there may be a [blr]delay[/blr] in passing meconium [blr]beyond 48[/blr] hours. Increase in [blr]fetal stress[/blr] (such as due to decrease in [blr]oxygenation[/blr]) can cause the fetus to [blr]pass meconium inside the womb[/blr]. Failure to pass meconium within [blr]24[/blr] hours may indicate conditions such as [blr]cystic fibrosis[/blr] which could cause meconium [blr]ileus[/blr] (due to [blr]very thick[/blr] meconium).
review.Hirschsprungs-disease: Condition where the large intestine is [blr]missing nerve cells[/blr] causing issues with [blr]motility[/blr]. Treatments include [blr]surgery[/blr] to [blr]bypass a part of the colon[/blr] or [blr]colostomy[/blr]. [blr]Ribbon [/blr] like stools are common.
review.casts: Extremity should be [blr]elvated[/blr] for the first [blr]24[/blr]-[blr]48[/blr] hours to assist with the [blr]blood flow[/blr]. Increasing [blr]pain[/blr] and [blr]pressure[/blr] may indicate [blr]compartment syndrome[/blr]. [blr]Edema[/blr] should be closely observed and should [blr]not increase further[/blr].
review.abdominal-examination:
Assist the client to a [blr]supine position[/blr] with [blr]knees flexed[/blr]. Auscultate using the [blr]diaphragm[/blr] of the stethoscope. Auscultate in the [blr]right lower[/blr] and the proceed [blr]counterclockwise[/blr]. Listen in each quadrant for [blr]1 mintue[/blr]. Use the [blr]bell[/blr] to listen for the [blr]bruit[/blr] over the aorta, [blr]renal[/blr] arteries and [blr]iliac[/blr] arteries.
Absent: No sounds heard for over [blr]3[/blr] - [blr]5[/blr] minutes. Hypoactive: [blr]1-2[/blr] sounds over [blr]2[/blr] minutes Normal: [blr]5[/blr]-[blr]30[/blr] sounds in [blr]1 minute[/blr]. Hyperactive: [blr]>30[/blr] sounds in [blr]1 minute[/blr]
review.scoliosis: Characterized by abormal [blr]lateral[/blr] curverature of the spine. Uneven [blr]shoulder[/blr] and [blr]hip[/blr] height is a symptom. Obeserve for assymetry or prominence of the [blr]ribcage[/blr] and [blr]scapulae[/blr]. Treatment is [blr]bracing[/blr] and [blr]sipnal fusion[/blr] surgery. Usually not accompanied by [blr]pain[/blr].
review.cystic-fibrosis: Infants exhibit [blr]salty skin[/blr], [blr]coughing[/blr] or [blr]wheezing[/blr], [blr]slow growth[/blr] even with [blr]normal appetite[/blr].
review.carbohydrates: Most common carb rich foods include [blr]grain products[/blr] (such as [blr]pasta[/blr], and [blr]bread[/blr]) and [blr]rice[/blr].
review.spina-bifida: A type of [blr]neural tube[/blr] defect where the spinal cord [blr]protrudes outside of the body[/blr]. Common symptoms are [blr]bowel obstruction[/blr] and [blr]constipation[/blr] due to [blr]loss of tone[/blr] and [blr]sensation[/blr] in the bowels, muscle [blr]discoordiantion[/blr], [blr]urinary incontinence[/blr], [blr]paralysis[/blr] of lower half. Spina bifida could be diagnosed with an [blr]ultrasound[/blr] around [blr]1st[/blr] trimester. ([blr]11[/blr]-[blr]14[/blr] weeks)
review.pediatric-constipation: Could be caused by [blr]psochosocial[/blr] factors such as [blr]fear of using the public toilet[/blr].
review.irritable-bowel-syndrome: Hallmark manifestation are [blr]alternating constipation and diarrhea[/blr]. Other symptoms include [blr]pain[/blr] with or after [blr]defecation[/blr], excessive [blr]flatulance[/blr] and [blr]abdominal bloating[/blr].
review.quad-screen: Blood test marker done to test for four markers - [blr]AFP[/blr], [blr]HCG[/blr], [blr]eastriol[/blr], [blr]inhibin A[/blr]. This test examines the risks of carrying baby with [blr]Down Syndrome[/blr] or [blr]Spina Bifida[/blr]. Usually done in the [blr]second trimester[/blr] (between [blr]15[/blr]-[blr]22nd[/blr] weeks).
review.Tay-Sachs-Disease: A rare genetic disorder that affects the [blr]buildup of an enzyme[/blr] that helps break down [blr]fatty substances[/blr]. Symptoms of [blr]slowed developement[/blr] appear around [blr]6 months[/blr], and often lead to [blr]death[/blr] at around [blr]4 years[/blr]. [blr]No[/blr] treatment [blr]exists[/blr].
review.liver-disease: Common to have [blr]hypokalemia[/blr] and increased [blr]ammonia[/blr]. [blr]Lactulose[/blr] could be administered to decrease ammonia by causing increase in [blr]bowel movements[/blr]. Correcting [blr]hypokalemia[/blr] also leads to reduction of ammonia levels (accumulation of which increases with [blr]low potassium[/blr]).
review.pediatric-adult-differences: Pediatric patients have a [blr]larger[/blr] proportion of surface area to body size than adults. This affects how [blr]fast[/blr] medications [blr]absorbed[/blr] through the skin take to get to [blr]systemic ciruclation[/blr]. Pediatric patients have a [blr]larger head[/blr] in proportion to body length. They are born with thier head comprising [blr]25[/blr]% of their body length, this proportion lessens until it's about [blr]12[/blr]% of thier overall body height at around 10 years of age. Pediatric patients have an immature [blr]blood-brain-barrier[/blr], so are more at risk of drugs affecting their [blr]CNS[/blr]. Pediatric patients do not have [blr]enlarged airway passages[/blr] compared to adults, they have [blr]smaller airwayas[/blr] and immature [blr]lungs[/blr]. This leads children to be more succeptible to [blr]respiratory illnesses[/blr] and viruses such as [blr]asthma[/blr], [blr]respiratory syncytial[/blr] virus, and [blr]bronchitis[/blr].
review.nursing-interventions: Classified as [blr]dependent[/blr] nursing interventions, [blr]independent[/blr] nursing interventions, and [blr]collaborative[/blr] interventions. Independent nursing interventions are actions that could be [blr]initiated[/blr] by the nurse wihtout needing a [blr]prescribed order[/blr] - [blr]monitoring[/blr] skin, [blr]assisting[/blr] the client with tasks, providing [blr]education[/blr]. Dependent nursing inteventions inlvolve a [blr]provider's order[/blr] - administering [blr]medications[/blr], starting [blr]input[/blr] and [blr]output[/blr] monitoring etc. Collaborative nursing interventions inlvove [blr]another member[/blr] of the [blr]health care te[/blr]am - for example consulting a [blr]psychiatrist[/blr] about the patients drug abuse problem.
